item.title: The UX of AI
item.description:
The UX of AI: Patterns and Mental Models

If you’re reading this, you’re probably tech-curious and familiar with AI chatbots. Actually, these days everyone is using tools like ChatGPT, Gemini, or Copilot.

We might love one and get frustrated with another, even when the interfaces look similar. This is where UX of AI becomes fascinating a fresh field that’s redefining how we design intelligent systems.

These Patterns Shape Our Experience

When I started researching, I discovered tiny interaction patterns that make or break our AI experience: inputs, suggestions, “stream of thought” responses, attachments, filters, voice & tone…

item.title: Sustainable Web Design
item.description:
Sustainable Web Design: A Case Study from the University of Lausanne

Digital products leave a massive carbon footprint. According to the Sustainable Web Manifesto: “If the Internet was a country, it would be the 4th largest polluter in the world.”

We need a sustainable web. While the need for sustainability has been around for a while, it’s now becoming a standard for digital products. Leading web organisations are providing practical and measurable recommendations for sustainable development, such as the Référentiel général d’écoconception de services numériques (RGESN) in France, or more recently, the W3C Web Sustainability Guidelines (WSG).

item.title: Using LLMs to Learn UX
item.description:
How to (Smartly) Use LLMs to Learn UX

Large Language Models (LLMs) have become almost irresistible tools for learning. They’re getting smarter, more specialised, and more helpful, delivering better results and empowering education. Yet, concerns are growing about dependency and the fear that LLMs might replace our own mental effort.

In this article, I’d like to share my thoughts on how to use LLMs to learn about UX, and what to keep in mind when doing so.

item.title: Choosing UX Reseach Methods
item.description:
How to Choose the Right Qualitative Research Methods (and Why I Struggle With This)

When starting a UX research project, the methods you pick can really shape the responses you get, and therefore your insights. Figuring out what you actually want to learn, then matching it to the right method, is key. To be honest, I often struggle with this step myself. I found this article super helpful for getting unstuck, so I wanted to share my take on it.
